July 30, 2006: Fiction
ANGELS FALL, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) When a chef from Boston, now
living in Wyoming, witnesses a murder, the locals won't believe her.
TWELVE SHARP, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $26.95.) The bounty hunter
Stephanie Plum must find a killer and rescue a kidnapped child.
COMING OUT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $20.) An attorney's household is thrown
into chaos when her daughters receive an invitation to a debutante ball.
CAN'T WAIT TO GET TO HEAVEN, by Fannie Flagg. (Random House, $29.95.) A
return to Elmwood Springs, Mo., the setting of Flagg's novel "Standing in the Rainbow."
BREAK NO BONES, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $25.95.) The forensic anthropologist
Temperance Brennan finds a fresh skeleton at an Indian burial ground in South
Carolina.
BEACH ROAD, by James Patterson and Peter de Jonge. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) An
East Hampton lawyer becomes involved in a highly publicized trial that pits locals
against the super-rich.
DANSE MACABRE, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $25.95.) Complications arise
when the vampire hunter Anita Blake discovers that she may be pregnant.
THE HUSBAND, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) A man whose wife is kidnapped has
60 hours to come up with a huge ransom.
THE BOOK OF THE DEAD, by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child. (Warner, $25.95.)
The final volume of a trilogy involving Secret Agent Aloysius Pendergast of the F.B.I.
and his criminal brother.
BLACK ORDER, by James Rollins. (Morrow, $24.95.) Sigma Force, a special military
unit, investigates worldwide mysteries that all originate with a secret Nazi experiment
smuggled out of wartime Berlin.
WATER FOR ELEPHANTS, by Sara Gruen (Algonquin, $24.95.) A young man — and
an elephant — save a Depression-era circus.
COVER OF NIGHT, by Linda Howard. (Ballantine, $27.) A young widow fights back
when armed intruders storm her bed-and-breakfast in rural Idaho.
AT RISK, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $21.95.) A Massachusetts state investigator
applies DNA and other forensic techniques to a cold murder case; written as a serial
for The New York Times Magazine.
SANDCASTLES, by Luanne Rice. (Bantam, $24.) An artist who has been jailed in
Ireland returns to his Connecticut home to find a conflicted wife and troubled
daughters.
Non-Fiction
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and
his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
CONSERVATIVES WITHOUT CONSCIENCE, by John W. Dean. (Viking, $25.95.)
The authoritarian character of contemporary conservative beliefs and attitudes.
THE ONE PERCENT DOCTRINE, by Ron Suskind. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) An
investigation of the Bush administration's strategic thinking and of the role of
ideology and personality in the decision to go to war.
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50;
updated and expanded edition, $30.) A columnist for The New York Times
analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy.
GODLESS, by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $27.95.) The columnist argues that
liberalism is a religion with sacraments, a creation myth and a clergy.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
MAYFLOWER, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $29.95.) How America began, from
the author of "In the Heart of the Sea."
FEEDING THE MONSTER, by Seth Mnookin. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) How the
Red Sox finally did it.
MYTHS, LIES, AND DOWNRIGHT STUPIDITY, by John Stossel. (Hyperion,
$24.95.) The "20/20" anchor questions conventional wisdom.
DISPATCHES FROM THE EDGE, by Anderson Cooper. (HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The CNN correspondent describes a year of covering the tsunami in Sri Lanka, the
war in Iraq and Hurricane Katrina.
WISDOM OF OUR FATHERS, by Tim Russert. (Random House, $22.95.) The
host of "Meet the Press'' presents readers' letters about their fathers in responseto
his book "Big Russ and Me.''
HEAT, by Bill Buford (Knopf, $25.95.) An editor changes his life by apprenticing in
a restaurant kitchen.
THE LONG TAIL, by Chris Anderson. (Hyperion, $24.95.) How the Internet has
changed business so that its future requires "selling less of more."
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
